Energy-conserving measures to be instituted
By ALAN HIRSCH
Homewood Vice President
George Benton will set forth
guidelines for University energy
conservation in a memorandum
early next week.
The memorandum will esta
blish "general" guidelines for tin
Closing of buildings on campus a:
well as the specifics of the reduc
tion in MSE Library hours,
Benton said. He stressed that the
guidelines in the memorandum
are tentative ones and that the
administration is still looking for
feedback on the building how
cuts.
The reduction of Librar)
hours —nine per week—is lest
severe than the originally forecasted cuts of 25 hours per week.
The Library will remain open
from 8:00 am to midnight Monday through Thursday, 8:00 am
to 10:00 pm Friday and Saturday, and 1:00 pm to midnight
Sundays. The new Library hours
are slated to go into effect in
early March.
Under the new
energy-conservation measures,
buildings on campus will have
their thermostats switched to
their night-time temperature settings at an earlier time. Most bu
ildings will go to evening temperature control at 5:00 pm. Evening College facilities will remain
on daytime temperature control
until 10:00 pm. At the present,
University buildings remain on
daytime control until 9:00 pm.
Most classroom buildings, such
as Gilman Hall, have a thermostat
setting of 55 degrees at night.
However, Benton said that build-.

ings which require stable temperatures, such as animal laboratories, will have their temperatures
maintained at night.
The memorandum will alsQ inform the community of an increase in airconditioned building
temperatures in the summer from
78 degrees to 80.
Also, lighting(for parking lots in
"outlying areas" will be turned
off at 1:00 am Sunday through
Thursday, and at 2:00am Friday
and Saturday.
Benton said That hours of operation have not yet been establi
shed for the Union or the Athle
tic Center.

A rough draft of the memorandum explains that the University
hopes to save $250,000 on these
conservation measures, the same
amount of money generated by a
$120 tuition increase or enough
money to give a three per cent
salary hike to all Homewood faculty.
Benton emphasized that
"there is still an opportunity for
people to respond to the
changes."
"We're taking it slow on purpose," he added:
The Student Council's Budget
Advisory Committee will survey
student opinion on the cut•
-

backs—primarily those affected
Library hours—starting Monday
and report their findings to
Benton later in the week.
Alan Fink, Chairman of the
BAC, indicated that he is "displeased" with what he has seen
of Benton's memorandum.
He said that Benton's failure
to include specifics for the Union
and Athletic Center—as he indicated he would—will prevent the
BAC from obtaining student opinion on any cutbacks there, and
consequently limit student input.
"The nature of the memo is
such that it will be very difficult
for students to react to it; but we

George Benton
will still try to get student reaction," Fink commented.
Fink said that by noon Monday, students will be stationed in
the Library to conduct the
survey.

Seven seniors to vie for Young Trustee slot
Seven seniors will vie, • for the
position of Young Trustee in the
initial balloting March 12, 13,
and 14.
The candidates are: Sally
Bergwerk, Charles Burhan, John
Colmers, Jack Coulter, Seth
Feltheimer, Tom Nathan, and
Jeff Oster.
The figure of seven represents
a decrease of six candidates from
last year's total of 13.
However, Victor Dates.
Secretary of the University, who
is running the election commented that the drop is "insignificant." "We could have substantial increase in the size of the ballot next year," he said.
In her undergraduate career,
Sally Bergwerk has served as head
of Orientation advising, been an
active member of ODK,the Hopkins leadership!fraternity, and has
worked on the Academic Services
Advisory Committee..
Burhan worked extensively on
the Spring Fair last year and has
served as manager of the Grad
Club.
Colmers is currently Student
Assistant to the Dean, and served
last year 'as Student Council Vice

President.
Jack Coulter, vice president of
the Blue Key Society, has played
varsity football and track, and is
a resident assistant housemaster.
Feltheimer is president of the
Senior Class and initiated the
Student Council's film series in
his first years at Hopkins.
Nathan, a member of TEP, has
been an undergraduate representative i to the Committee on Undergraduate Studies for the last
two years.
A Biology major, Oster has
participated in several student activities organizations in his years
at Hopkins.
According to the guidelines for
the election, undergraduates will
receive biographical information
about the candidates. A forum
will be held, enabling the seniors
to issue statements about their
candidacy.
Students will elect three of the
candidates for final selection by
the Trustees. A trustee sub-committee will recommend one of
the three to the Board of Trustees for final approval. The
Young Trustees serve a four-year
tenure.

The Young Trustee program
began in 1971 on the recommendation of then-President Milton
Eisenhower.
Responsibilities
Dates remarked,"the recent alumni had had a significant impact—they bring to the Board a
different range of experience."

The Young Trustee has "all
the rights and responsibilities of
any other board member," Dates
observed.
Shep Hoffman was elected
Young Trustee last year. Other
Young Trustees currently on the
Board are Michael Hill, Steven
Mahinka, and James Shannon.

Commemoration celebrated today
The University will commemorate its 99th anniversary today
with ceremonies beginning at
3:00 pm in Shriver Hall.
Terry Sanford, Duke University President and former North
Carolina governor, will delivet
the main' address and receive ar
honorary degree as the highlight
of the Commemoration Day
Dr. George W. Corner, an alumnus of the School of Medicine and professor emeritus of embryology at the Hopkins Hospital, will also receive an honorary
degree for his many years of research in human reproduction.
The afternoon presentation:
will be Preceded by the academic
procession. led by Chief Marshall

Dr. Russell H. Morgan, dean of
the School of Medicine and vice
president for the Unviersity's
health divisions. Other marshalls
for commemoration will be Drs.
William A. Huggins, Richard A.
Macksey, Owen 0. Philipps, and
Robert Pond of the Homewood
Faculty.
Also slated for the -afternoot
proceedings will be the invoca
tion by University Chaplain
Chester A. Wickwire. Music will
be provided by the GO-ucherHopkins Chorus, under the supervision of George Woodhead, and
the Washington Ensemble. Robert
Harvey, chairman of the Board of
Trustees, will deliver the opening
remarks, prior to President

Muller's presentation of the honorary degrees.
To enable students, administrators, and faculty members to
attend the Commemoration Day
ceremony, all classes and offices
on the Homewood campus will
be suspended at 2:00 pm. Evening College courses will be held
tomorrow as scheduled.
A lifelong resident of North
Carolina, Sanford received his undergraduate education and law
degree at the University of North
Carolina. He was first elected to
political office in 1953, when he
became a State Senator from
North Carolina. Seven years later,
he was elected the state's governor.

The News-Letter's survey of area college bookstores leads
to several direct conclusions about the Follett's JHU Book
Center, which must be stomached, however bitter may be the
crow carrion. For one, the prices for textbooks are in line
with those of other college bookstores as the HAG in its
report stated. The News-Letter, like many others, leaped rather too hastily on the HAC's ad hoc committee for accurately assessing an incredible situation, where the causes are out
of the hands of the local management.
Secondly, the survey points out that Hopkins students are
paying too much for non-text supplies. While we believe the
University should act promptly to rectify the situation, students, regardless of what happens, are fully capable of going
off campus for these supplies, sacrificing shopping convenience to save a little money.
Third, and most important, the survey supports another
common student suppositions about the Book Center: its
auxiliary services are woefully inadequate, especially in comparison to other bookstores.
It may be-too much to hope that something substantive
can be effected to lower prices here. To help ease the situadon, however, the Book Center can institute a more reasonable book return policy and a used book service. Such action
would serve to lower a student's bookbill, and would require
the cooperation of the faculty as well as the Book Center.
In the meantime, if students wish to improve the situation
themselves, they can institute their own used book service,
vis a vis the Student Council, as has been done at many other
colleges throughout the country. Students are still paying too
, much for books at Hopkins. But, with a little effort on the
part of the administration, the faculty, the Book Center, and
the student body, improvements that will result in money
saved can be made.

The recent criticisms of Margie
Kolchin's article strikingly reveal how little many Americans have learned from
our experience in Vietnam. Apparently
very little of the raging debates of just a
few years ago has filtered into our national consciousness. (Perhaps these writers
were too young at that time to have followed the debates).
I found little evidence in these articles to indicate that the authors have read
anything but American newspapers on
Vietnam. Their pieces reflect most of the
ill-founded assumptions held by our government as it entered, escalated and perpetuated the war. Although there is plenty to object to in these two articles on
factual and historical grounds,(for example—"the North Vietnamese Government
is also corrupt," and "there is a sizeable
black market in North Vietnam"), my
major objections are to the assumptions
that these young men so unquestioningly
accept.
Assumption No. 1: North [Vietnam is a
`totalitarian' nation, ruled by dictatorial
elites that crush basic human rights.
True, North Vietnam does not subscribe to the individualistic, procedural
freedoms of Western nations, but that by
no means proves that there is no human
liberty in North Vietnam. Economic free'cloml meant little more than unending
poverty and exploitation to the vast majority of Vietnam's population before the
Revolution. Freedom to these people
means much more than freedom of press
or religion. "Liberation" is the act of
breaking down the social relationships
that ensured perpetual poverty and ecoIL

nomic subjugation. After removing the
class of landlords and merchants that held
this system together, the Vietnamese
communists are building an egalitarian
social order based on cooperation, not
competition, and on collectivism, not individualism. (For eyewitness accounts of
the same process of peasant revolution in
China, read Fanshen, by William Hinton
or China Shakes the World, by Jack
Belden.). It is this program to end the
economic and spiritual subjugation of the
peasantry that gave the communist movement the strength and support that it has.
With this historical process in mind, the
distinctions between the Cold Warrior's
labels 'totalitarianism' and 'democracy'
become increasingly blurred.
Assumption No. 2: North Vietnam is
engaged in military aggression upon its
southern neighbor, South Vietnam— a
separate, independent nation.
The boundary between North and
South was set up by the 1954 Geneva
Accords, which subsequently broke down
when elections were not held in the
South, as stipulated in the agreement.
(The southern region of Vietnam was
where French colonial forces had been
driven to after being badly beaten by
Vietnamese revolutionary forces). Instead
of holding free elections, a so-called 'democratic' regime was established in the
South—a regime which has subsequently
been bolstered by American aid and military force, and which has somehow been
transformed in our eyes into a separate,
independent "people". When the Geneva
accords broke down, revolutionary troops
began to infiltrate back into the South to

The News-Letter's survey of area college bookstores leads
to several direct conclusions about the Follett's JHU Book
Center, which must be stomached, however bitter may be the
crow carrion. For one, the prices for textbooks are in line
with those of other college bookstores as the HAG in its
report stated. The News-Letter, like many others, leaped rather too hastily on the HAC's ad hoc committee for accurately assessing an incredible situation, where the causes are out
of the hands of the local management.
Secondly, the survey points out that Hopkins students are
paying too much for non-text supplies. While we believe the
University should act promptly to rectify the situation, students, regardless of what happens, are fully capable of going
off campus for these supplies, sacrificing shopping convenience to save a little money.
Third, and most important, the survey supports another
common student suppositions about the Book Center: its
auxiliary services are woefully inadequate, especially in comparison to other bookstores.
It may be-too much to hope that something substantive
can be effected to lower prices here. To help ease the situadon, however, the Book Center can institute a more reasonable book return policy and a used book service. Such action
would serve to lower a student's bookbill, and would require
the cooperation of the faculty as well as the Book Center.
In the meantime, if students wish to improve the situation
themselves, they can institute their own used book service,
vis a vis the Student Council, as has been done at many other
colleges throughout the country. Students are still paying too
, much for books at Hopkins. But, with a little effort on the
part of the administration, the faculty, the Book Center, and
the student body, improvements that will result in money
saved can be made.

Vietnam: a difficult lesson for Americans to learn
By ANDREW WALDER
The recent criticisms of Margie
Kolchin's article strikingly reveal how little many Americans have learned from
our experience in Vietnam. Apparently
very little of the raging debates of just a
few years ago has filtered into our national consciousness. (Perhaps these writers
were too young at that time to have followed the debates).
I found little evidence in these articles to indicate that the authors have read
anything but American newspapers on
Vietnam. Their pieces reflect most of the
ill-founded assumptions held by our government as it entered, escalated and perpetuated the war. Although there is plenty to object to in these two articles on
factual and historical grounds,(for example—"the North Vietnamese Government
is also corrupt," and "there is a sizeable
black market in North Vietnam"), my
major objections are to the assumptions
that these young men so unquestioningly
accept.
Assumption No. 1: North [Vietnam is a
`totalitarian' nation, ruled by dictatorial
elites that crush basic human rights.
True, North Vietnam does not subscribe to the individualistic, procedural
freedoms of Western nations, but that by
no means proves that there is no human
liberty in North Vietnam. Economic free'cloml meant little more than unending
poverty and exploitation to the vast majority of Vietnam's population before the
Revolution. Freedom to these people
means much more than freedom of press
or religion. "Liberation" is the act of
breaking down the social relationships
that ensured perpetual poverty and ecoIL

nomic subjugation. After removing the
class of landlords and merchants that held
this system together, the Vietnamese
communists are building an egalitarian
social order based on cooperation, not
competition, and on collectivism, not individualism. (For eyewitness accounts of
the same process of peasant revolution in
China, read Fanshen, by William Hinton
or China Shakes the World, by Jack
Belden.). It is this program to end the
economic and spiritual subjugation of the
peasantry that gave the communist movement the strength and support that it has.
With this historical process in mind, the
distinctions between the Cold Warrior's
labels 'totalitarianism' and 'democracy'
become increasingly blurred.
Assumption No. 2: North Vietnam is
engaged in military aggression upon its
southern neighbor, South Vietnam— a
separate, independent nation.
The boundary between North and
South was set up by the 1954 Geneva
Accords, which subsequently broke down
when elections were not held in the
South, as stipulated in the agreement.
(The southern region of Vietnam was
where French colonial forces had been
driven to after being badly beaten by
Vietnamese revolutionary forces). Instead
of holding free elections, a so-called 'democratic' regime was established in the
South—a regime which has subsequently
been bolstered by American aid and military force, and which has somehow been
transformed in our eyes into a separate,
independent "people". When the Geneva
accords broke down, revolutionary troops
began to infiltrate back into the South to

These assumptions lead Joe Griffith to

rupt the balance of power in Southeast
Asia...causing many dislocations" and
(gasp!)"a loss of influence by the U.S. in
world affairs, if not realignment by some
countries". Here we have a "broader
view.' of the situation that is based solely
on American interests, and that totally

interests and needs of the majority of the
Vietnamese. This is the point of view that
totally disregards the goals (in human and
social terms) of the Vietnamese Revolution, and that argues for a perpetuation

American-dependent Saigon regime.

touch on the surface of the immensely
complex issues in Vietnam. I urge anyone
who was satisfied with the arguments presented in the News-Letter articles by

The Origins of Revolution, and Frances
Fitzgerald's Fire in the Lake are excellent
histories. The Pentagon Papers and Daniel
Ellsberg's Papers on the War are essential
accounts of American involvement. Lastly, any of Senator Fulbright's books—The
Arrogance of Power, The Crippled Giant,
and The Pentagon Propaganda Machine are
readable, brief, but more thorough arguments on the issues presented here. But

of their arguments—follow up their
sources and footnotes. After doing so it
